Patch Set 26: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully merged

We can't be calling rand() in a unit test.  That defeats a lot of the purpose of a unit test if the results are random.

For now, lets just pick a number for the unit tests to use, and in the future, we can either create a fuzzer, or at least seed these with a value so test results are reproducible.

This is not part of unit-test.

This is actually a component of cper-generate (CLI) & it uses this rand() / generate_random_bytes() method everywhere (including header / section-descriptors) to produce sample CPERs.

I'm not quite sure what to use it for, and we don't really use this functionality, but I've updated it to keep it functioning.
Why - 1?
There is already 2 * sizeof(UINT64) in sizeof(EFI_NVIDIA_ERROR_DATA) - enough for numRegs=1
Do we need descriptions of these?  "code" and "name" aren't terribly descriptive of what they are.
This follows the conventions used elsewhere - in header, sectionDescriptor (since NVIDIA docs say this is just the UEFI-defined severity)
An array of size 1, but with the plural "Registers" doesn't look correct, and I can't tell what was intended.
This can have 1 or more Address/Value pairs & needs to be allocated based on NumberRegs
you're trying to do a dynamic sized struct then?  Then don't make it a size of 1.  Make it an abstract size.
Done
[] & [0] were both rejected by the compiler... had to use [1] & then use -1 in the math
(rejected by the CI actually)
Tricking the compiler isn't the answer.  we need to understand why CI rejected it.  I'm assuming because dynamic structures aren't allowed in the coding standard?

It is actually failing when compiling the C++ files in tests/

[3/4] Compiling C++ object tests/cper-tests.p/ir-tests.cpp.o
FAILED: tests/cper-tests.p/ir-tests.cpp.o 
c++ -Itests/cper-tests.p -Itests -I../tests -I. -I.. -I/usr/include/json-c -fdiagnostics-color=always -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -Wall -Winvalid-pch -Wextra -Wpedantic -Werror -std=c++23 -Og -g '-DLIBCPER_JSON_SPEC="/home/krajagopalan/_nvidia/libcper/specification/json/cper-json.json"' -DGTEST_HAS_PTHREAD=1 -fpermissive -MD -MQ tests/cper-tests.p/ir-tests.cpp.o -MF tests/cper-tests.p/ir-tests.cpp.o.d -o tests/cper-tests.p/ir-tests.cpp.o -c ../tests/ir-tests.cpp
In file included from ../tests/../sections/cper-section.h:7,
                 from ../tests/ir-tests.cpp:15:
../tests/../sections/../edk/Cper.h:1405:34: error: ISO C++ forbids flexible array member ‘Register’ [-Werror=pedantic]
 1405 |         EFI_NVIDIA_REGISTER_DATA Register[ ];
      |                                  ^~~~~~~~
cc1plus: all warnings being treated as errors
seems like a missing extern C somewhere?
Fixed by -Wno-pedantic to cpp_args in tests/meson.build
Sure, I guess that works.
Using [1] because the -Wno-pedantic option needs to be used in every c++ project that comsumes libcper.

this math looks suspect.  Where is the -1 and *2 coming from?  This looks similar to the other code we already had to replace that was mallocing 2X the required space because of indexing issues.  Is that what happened here?

This isn't that issue.

I added 2 new UINT64 fields to the struct & accounted for it in the math (sections/cper-section-nvidia.c had the math with the old struct; generator/sections/gen-section-nvidia.c did not have it at all).
This is part of the Update to NVIDIA section schema (adds "registers")

2 new UINT64 fields would be 32 bytes, not 2, so I'm not sure how that works?

please update this to use sizeof and variables where appropriate.
I've updated this part & also added a unit-test for NVIDIA section decode
why are we moding the field?  I don't think it was initted anywhere?
The memory is allocated & inited with random bytes. This changeset needs this value to be % 4
Maybe leave a comment that severity is only valid between 0 and 3 then?
This would be the first use of offsetof or a variable length struct in the codebase that I can see.  Are we sure that variable length CPER binaries are allowed?  Do we have any docs to that effect?
nvm.  foudnn them.
Does this need updated with your new register structure?
Done
Any reason we need both name and code here?  Doesn't name map 1:1 with code?
Having just one of them will require consumers of libcper to implement a "name = mappingOf(code)" (or vice-versa) if they need the property that's not required.
Should these decode to names rather than just integers?
I'll 1st check whether that mapping proprietary, then take it up.
I think the problem with this is the size of the structure varies across compilers. The other suggestion I made on this patch doesn't have that problem.

C++ code doesn't need access to the members of this struct, so not adding an accessor function at all.

Also, compilation fails over the __attribute__ that you had suggested, so only using the rest of the code to ensure sizeof(EFI_NVIDIA_ERROR_DATA) stays the same.

Yeah, so I have other tricks for the `__attribute__((counted_by(...)))`:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/include/libpldm/compiler.h

Not sure if you want to apply the same approach here, but it makes it possible to find issues when the compiler supports the attribute.
Done
